htmlContent:
Node.js Guide

Node.js is a server-side JavaScript runtime that enables building fast, scalable, and high-performance backend applications. It uses an event-driven, non-blocking I/O model that makes it lightweight and efficient.

Key Features

  • Asynchronous non-blocking I/O for high concurrency
  • Event Loop & Performance optimization
  • Express.js Framework for building APIs
  • REST API Development & routing
  • Database Integration (MongoDB, MySQL, PostgreSQL)
  • Cross-platform support and large ecosystem of packages

Best Practices

  • Organize code into modules and services
  • Handle async/await properly with error handling
  • Use environment variables for configuration
  • Write clean and maintainable code
  • Log errors and monitor performance

Example: Simple Express Server

const express = require('express');
const app = express();

app.get('/', (req, res) => {
  res.send('Hello from Node.js!');
});

app.listen(3000, () => console.log('Server running on port 3000'));

Next Steps

  • Integrate Node.js with MongoDB or SQL databases
  • Build RESTful APIs with authentication & authorization
  • Use WebSockets for real-time applications
  • Write unit tests for server-side code
  • Deploy backend on cloud platforms like Heroku, Render, or AWS

By following these guidelines, you can build robust, scalable, and maintainable backend applications using Node.js and Express.js.
